name: Waveform
description: Navigate the beauty and hazards of the solar system while riding a wave of light through 100+ levels in this innovative action-puzzle game!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or higher Processor: 1 GHz Memory: 512 MB Hard Disk Space: 660 MB Video Card: OpenGL compatible graphics card with 128 MB of memory Sound: Any sound card capable of stereo output

reviews.review_text: One of those indie games with dozens of levels and simple game mechanics. You change wave length and frequency that ship will follow. The goal is to avoid obstacles while catching as many plasma as possible. I don't know why, but it's quite fun for first hour...
I, personally, am not a fan of this game. Why? Because I suck at it. Horribly.  But would I recommend it?  Definitely. It's awesome and looks beautiful. It's well put together.

This is a pretty damn fun puzzle game with a very simple concept that scales appropriately in difficulty over time. Admittedly some of the features introduced can be quite obnoxious (particularly wormholes) but it's a genuinely enjoyable challenge of skill and timing.  Then you get to the last set of planets and are immediately gated by obnoxious requirements. You see, at each level you are scored a percentage, which awards you a number of stars rounded down to the lowest ten e.g. 79% = 7 stars! Can you see where this is going? Waveform ultimately turns into an obnoxiously grind-fest wherein you're playing the same level over and over to scrap an extra few points out to potentially have enough stars to unlock another level or two. This star requirement is present throughout the game but it really ramps up towards the end.  Honestly it's quite a fun game, but I can't imagine actually finishing it. Probably the perfect tablet game for killing time as you gather those last few stars at a glacial pace over the course of a few weeks. Not worth buying on Steam unfortunately.

While I did enjoy Waveform immensely, it falls just barely shy of being one of my favorites. It's fresh gameplay is strangely addicting, and the speed and movement of the game allows for a lot of adaptability and logic from the player's end. The game doesn't have any crippling flaws. Whenever I messed up, it was my fault not the games. But the game seems to have a bit of a resentful attitude towards adequacy. When I got to the Mercury and Sun levels, the game continuously smacked me in the forehead, saying, '450 stars!? You call that good! Go back and get some more, you ingrateful fool!'. For most of those levels, I'd continuously roll my eyes as I'd scroll back to Pluto and Neptune to replay levels I had already beat just to continue playing the game. If this doesn't bother you or you're rather the perfectionist, this game is perfect for you. I'd just advise caution to people who like to keep their casual games... casual.

I rarely feel this way about steam games; Waveform is definitely underpriced! I was expecting a very quick, lite and shallow game. It is none of that. I'll go into a bit more detail about this peculiar game.  It is the perfect game to play on a Saturday morning drinking a warm coffee. Mmmmm coffee.  It starts out quite easy, maybe a little too much so, and then takes you on a very skillful and unique journey. I love the mechanics, the mirrors and the bonus 'arrange' levels. The ambiance is also spot on. The music is hit-and-miss, with some great tracks and some not-so-great ones.  Replayability is through the roof. If you want to master this game, you will need to invest quite some time in it, which is good.  I'd say absolutely try this if you are adventurous in the games you enjoy. Or you want to experience short, novel and deep gameplay.

Waveform's really cool, a medium paced, gentle, abstract panic-inducer. The controls and gameplay are unique and basic, but like most great games, it takes a while to master. Think of a race game, but you're controlling a waveform .. Um. View video of it if you can and add a lot of active interaction. Every level you play can be beaten on the first time through, but you get bonuses in the game based on how well you do, so there is strong incentive to replay each level a few times to improve your rating on each. This might sound repetitive, but Waveform is excellent about each level being similar but different enough to keep players interested. Great music helps as well. So far, I haven't seen levels take longer than a few minutes, which also helps with replays, but that creates a very strong 'Just one more level' effect. Waveform is like a puzzle race... sort of. I like it quite a bit. Have a look at it if you like good games that are off the beaten path.
